summary: An insightful interview with Susumu Tonegawa where he shares his impressions and recommendations about scientific development, emphasizing the importance of government support and international cooperation.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a white background featuring red and gray circles, transitioning to a logo with the text "BCN Biblioteca del Congreso Nacional de Chile ENTREVISTA A SUSUMU TONEGAWA PREMIO NOBEL DE FISIOLOGÍA O MEDICINA (1987) Enero 2014." The scene then shifts to a dimly lit auditorium filled with people, focusing on a man in a suit and tie seated among the audience. The video then displays a black screen with the text "¿Cuál es su impresión sobre este III Congreso del Futuro?" (What is your impression of this III Congress of the Future?). Following this, a man with gray hair, wearing a suit and an orange lanyard, is shown speaking in front of a wooden background. The subtitles read, "todos los invitados son mis amigos y científicos extremadamente buenos todos" (all the guests are my friends and extremely good scientists) and "Con todos ellos hemos pasado" (With all of them we have passed). The man continues speaking, with the subtitles changing to "independientemente de esta reunión que tuvimos hoy" (regardless of this meeting we had today). The video concludes with another black screen displaying the text "¿Cómo piensa que deber" (How do you think it should).
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with light, ambient instrumental music setting a calm mood. This transitions into a male speaker, sounding relatively informal, suggesting something about the meeting is unique. The background buzzes with indistinct chatter, indicating a social or event-like setting. The same male speaker expresses enjoyment of the event and discusses the quality and camaraderie among the invited scientists. The background noise persists throughout. The clip concludes with the same male speaker expressing interest in possible future arrangements.

events_list.video_caption: The video features Susumu Tonegawa, a Nobel Prize winner in Physiology or Medicine, seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling. He is dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and an orange lanyard. Throughout the video, he speaks about the importance of organizing resources, stating that while it is not easy to remove physical resources, it is beneficial to do so. The subtitles in Spanish translate his words, emphasizing the need for order and the value of resource management. The video also highlights Chile's export of copper as a significant resource. The setting remains consistent, with the focus on Tonegawa's expressions and gestures as he delivers his message.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker who sounds thoughtful, discussing something being physically far away and not easy. He mentions it would be nice if they could do more, and he has heard that Chile has a lot of resources, specifically mentioning copper export.

events_list.video_caption: The video features Susumu Tonegawa, a Nobel Prize winner in Physiology or Medicine, seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling. He is dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, with an orange lanyard around his neck. Throughout the video, he speaks passionately, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The subtitles in Spanish translate his words, discussing the importance of science and its division into basic and applied research. He highlights the challenges faced by countries without resources in supporting basic research, which he argues takes time but ultimately transforms society. The setting remains consistent, with the richly decorated background providing a formal atmosphere. The video captures Tonegawa's earnest expression and dynamic gestures as he conveys his message.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the government's role in funding science, differentiating between basic and applied research. He speaks with a measured, thoughtful tone, noting the challenges of supporting basic research in countries with limited resources, emphasizing that the "turnaround of basic research to the human society takes long time."

events_list.video_caption: The video features an older man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, wearing an orange lanyard. He is seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling in the background, suggesting a formal or official setting. Throughout the video, the man speaks and gestures with his hands, emphasizing his points. The subtitles in Spanish provide context to his speech, discussing the importance of industry in lifting nations and providing economic stability, as well as its support for scientific production. The man appears engaged and passionate about the topic, with his facial expressions and hand movements reflecting his enthusiasm. The subtitles translate to: "The industry lifts nations and provides a certain level of stability to the economy," "but also provides permanent support to scientific production," and "It seems that currently in Chile, the conditions are there to achieve that." The video maintains a consistent atmosphere, focusing on the man's discussion and the significance of industry and scientific support.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing industrialized nations and their ability to support basic science, mentioning Chile specifically as an example. His tone is conversational.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an older man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, seated in front of a richly carved wooden backdrop. He is wearing an orange lanyard around his neck. Throughout the video, the man speaks, and subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen in Spanish, translating to English as follows: "It seems that currently in Chile, there are the conditions to achieve that" and "I think it would be good if governments and their leaders recognized that by supporting science and higher education, they would have many talents." The man gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The setting appears to be a formal or official environment, possibly a conference or meeting room, with the ornate wooden paneling adding to the atmosphere of importance and tradition. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and his message, with no significant changes in the environment or his appearance.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a single male speaker with a measured tone. He expresses that, "it would be nice, it would be good" if government leaders recognized the importance of supporting science and higher education, specifically graduate school. He notes that there are many talented and enthusiastic students.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an interview with Susumu Tonegawa, a Nobel Prize winner in Physiology or Medicine, set against a backdrop of ornate wooden paneling. Tonegawa, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, speaks passionately about the importance of scientific development and the value of supporting it. He gestures with his hands to emphasize his points, and subtitles in Spanish appear on the screen, translating his words. The subtitles read, "no apoyarlos es una perdida para las naciones" (not supporting them is a loss for nations) and "pero hay una cosa muy clara en la tradición japonesa" (but there is one very clear thing in Japanese tradition). The video transitions to a black screen with white text asking, "¿Qué podemos aprender en Chile del desarrollo científico?" (What can we learn in Chile from scientific development?). Tonegawa continues to speak, discussing Japan's lack of natural resources and the importance of scientific advancement. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the text "Susumu Tonegawa, Premio Nobel de Fisiología o Medicina" (Susumu Tonegawa, Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine).
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker emphasizing that without support, it's a waste for the nation. Transitioning, the male speaker discusses the unique situation of Japan having few natural resources and emphasizing human beings as its primary resource. He notes Japan's tradition of investing heavily in education to develop skills. He mentioned that even during medieval times, schools were accessible even to ordinary people on the street. He concludes by stating his belief that education is important.  Background music plays with a peaceful and ambient tone, with prominent electronic instruments throughout the clip.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an older man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, speaking in front of a wooden panel background. He wears an orange lanyard around his neck. Throughout the video, he gestures with his hands while speaking, emphasizing his points. The subtitles in Spanish provide context to his speech, discussing Japan's efforts to catch up in science and technology after the war, the value of efficiency in Japanese culture, and the balance between being serious and having a sense of humor. The man's expressions and gestures convey his passion and conviction about the topic. The setting appears to be a formal environment, possibly a conference or lecture hall, with the wooden paneling adding a sense of tradition and seriousness to the atmosphere. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man and his message, with no significant changes in the background or setting.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Japan and their efforts to catch up with the Western world in science and technology. He notes that while Chileans are diligent, Japanese people are particularly so, describing this as a national feature. He then criticizes them for overworking and not taking enough vacations, suggesting it's an extreme. However, he acknowledges the merit of diligence and seriousness in their work. Quiet ambient sound is perceived in the background as the speaker talks. A melancholic piano piece begins as the speaker concludes.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an older man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, wearing an orange lanyard. He is seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling and carvings, suggesting a formal or academic setting. Throughout the video, the man speaks, with subtitles in Spanish appearing at the bottom of the screen, translating his words into English. He gestures with his hands, emphasizing his points. The subtitles discuss the importance of increasing basic sciences, the significance of postgraduate research, and the need for specialized training for young people. The man's expressions and gestures convey a sense of passion and conviction about the topics he is discussing. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere, focusing on the man's dialogue and the importance of the subjects he addresses.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker with a thoughtful and measured tone, suggesting that leaders should "read out" and "think carefully" about how to support basic science. He specifies that this includes the university system, with the research graduate school being very important for the training of young people, especially in their 20s.

events_list.video_caption: The video features an older man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, wearing an orange lanyard. He is seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling and carvings, suggesting a formal or official setting. Throughout the video, the man speaks and gestures with his hands, emphasizing his points. Subtitles in Spanish appear on the screen, translating to English as follows: "if we want to raise the level of science," "we need to have a system that the government can support," "it's not just about having high budgets," "but if it's enough so that you don't have to do other work," and "you can focus on your research." The man's expressions and gestures convey a sense of urgency and importance regarding the topic of scientific funding and support. The video maintains a consistent atmosphere, focusing on the man's message and the formal environment around him.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a man speaking in a calm, measured tone about raising the standard of science. He says, "you have to have a system" where the government gives fellowship, and money should be sufficient.  He emphasizes the need to devote entire time to training, mentioning that this is done in good universities in Japan.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, is seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling. He wears an orange lanyard around his neck. The man is speaking, and subtitles appear on the screen in Spanish, translating to "that is how it is done in the United States." He gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The subtitles change to "in Japan, the most important universities support their students," followed by "and only students from rich families can go to the best universities." The man continues to speak, occasionally touching his face, and the subtitles remain on the screen throughout the video. The setting appears to be a formal environment, possibly a lecture hall or conference room, with a serious and academic atmosphere.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker is talking about America and Japan, specifically in the context of top universities. He says, "not enough in America...Japan is not enough, actually." He mentions that many students at Tokyo universities are supported by their parents, suggesting that the children of richer parents tend to attend these universities because of the need for financial support. His tone is neutral. The audio includes the sound of speech.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, an older man with gray hair, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt, and blue tie, is seated in a room with ornate wooden paneling. He wears an orange lanyard around his neck. The man is speaking and gesturing with his hands, emphasizing his points. The subtitles in Spanish appear on the screen, translating to "In the United States, the situation is more egalitarian because you don't need rich parents to study," followed by "I don't know how it is in Chile, but I understand that here the leaders of the government have good intentions." The man continues to speak, and the subtitles change to "that they have expressed here and that I hope they put into practice." The setting appears formal, possibly a conference or meeting room, with a serious and professional atmosphere. The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is passionately discussing the topic at hand.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing his perception of fairness and leadership. He contrasts America, where he believes things are more even regardless of parents' wealth, with the situation in an unnamed "city." He mentions leaders of the government, referring to a senator he heard speaking earlier in the day, hoping the senator practices what he preaches. His tone is reflective and hopeful.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a suit and tie, wearing an orange lanyard, speaking in a room with wooden paneling and ornate carvings. He gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The subtitles in Spanish translate to "but leaders must recognize that in the long term, science and technology are the real power of nations, so it is a long-term plan to initiate a system that encourages universities to create science and research that can create science." The scene transitions to a large auditorium filled with people, where a presentation is being shown on a screen. The subtitles continue, "and research that can create science, where people and sufficient resources participate." The audience is diverse, with individuals dressed in various styles, some taking notes or using their phones. The room is grand, with high ceilings, chandeliers, and a large mural on the wall, creating an atmosphere of importance and formality. The video captures the essence of a significant event focused on the importance of science and technology in national development.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a man's voice, speaking in a slightly accented tone, emphasizing that "a leader should recognize that in the long run, science and science-based technology is the real power of the nation." He goes on to discuss the need for a long-term plan to develop a research and funding system that promotes good science, ensuring there are enough people and money dedicated to it. He also mentions the importance of opening up the country.

events_list.video_caption:
The video opens with a scene of a diverse audience seated in a formal setting, attentively listening to a speaker at a podium. The speaker, dressed in a suit and tie, passionately addresses the crowd, emphasizing the importance of opening borders and accepting foreign students, as indicated by the subtitles in Spanish: 'hay que abrir los países y aceptar estudiantes del extranjero' (we need to open the countries and accept foreign students). The audience, composed of individuals of various ages and attire, shows engagement, with some taking notes and others listening intently. The setting is ornate, featuring wooden paneling and a large Chilean flag in the background, suggesting a governmental or institutional venue.

The focus then shifts to a close-up of the speaker, who continues to elaborate on the benefits of international student exchange, with subtitles reading 'de Sudamérica y de otros lugares' (from South America and other places) and 'vendrán más estudiantes y mejorarán las oportunidades' (more students will come and improve opportunities). The speaker's gestures and expressions convey a sense of urgency and conviction. The scene transitions to a wider shot of the audience, showing their attentive and engaged demeanor, with some individuals raising their hands, possibly to ask questions or make comments.

The video then features a close-up of the speaker, who is now identified as a distinguished figure in a suit and tie, with an orange lanyard around his neck. He passionately discusses the unique aspects of the North American experience, as indicated by the subtitles: 'La singularidad norteamericana' (The uniqueness of North America) and 'puedes ver todo el mundo' (you can see the whole world). His expressive hand gestures and animated facial expressions emphasize his points, creating a dynamic and engaging atmosphere.

The video concludes with a transition to a graphic displaying the logo and text 'BCN Biblioteca del Congreso Nacional de Chile ENTREVISTA A SU CIENTÍFICO' (BCN National Library of Chile INTERVIEW WITH ITS SCIENTIST), followed by 'IA O MEDICINA (1987)' (IA OR MEDICINE (1987)). This graphic serves as an introduction to the interview segment, providing context and setting the stage for the discussion. The overall atmosphere is formal and informative, with a focus on the importance of international collaboration and the unique opportunities it presents.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker discussing the acceptance of international students. He suggests starting with South America, and emphasizes the importance of a good funding system to attract graduate students. He believes it increases the probability of students coming, and notes that in America, the focus is on looking at the whole world when hiring graduate students, not just American students.
